Macron seeks consensus and pledges to work 'until the very last second' in penultimate New Year's Eve address
subhead: The president avoided reviewing his record, simply assuring that France 'is holding firm.' While he outlined three major projects for 2026 – voluntary national service, digital majority at age 15, and end-of-life care – he seems to have implicitly acknowledged his own powerlessness.

Israel says 'will enforce' ban on 37 NGOs in Gaza
subhead: The government said that these international aid groups, including Doctors Without Borders, World Vision International and Oxfam, had not complied with a deadline to disclose information on their Palestinian staff. They will be required to cease their operations by March 1.

title: Early Christian fresco depicting Jesus as the Good Shepherd discovered in Turkey
subhead: One month after Pope Leo XIV's visit, Turkish authorities announced the discovery in Iznik, Anatolia, of a depiction of Christ in a well-preserved burial chamber.

title: Physical activity can reduce the risk of death: 'It's very hard to find a drug that can do that'
subhead: Longevity physician Peter Attia highlights in his book the importance of physical exercise to combat what he calls the 'four horsemen': cardiovascular disease, cancer, dementia, and metabolic disorders.

title: Bulgaria joins the euro divided, in political crisis and without a budget
subhead: The Balkan country adopted the European single currency on January 1, but the population remains unenthusiastic. The country only has a caretaker government and corruption is endemic.

New Year's Eve 2015 in Cologne: The night that traumatized thousands of women and shook Germany
subhead: On New Year's Eve in 2015, more than 1,000 women were sexually assaulted in Cologne by groups of men, many from North Africa and the Middle East, triggering a fierce debate over Germany's refugee policy. Ten years on, victims say their trauma was politicized, as they continue to live with the consequences of that night.

title: Brigitte Bardot's 30 years of sympathy for the far right
subhead: Convicted five times for racist remarks, the actress – whose foundation announced her death on Sunday, December 28 – remained one of the only French celebrities to openly embrace far-right views.

title: 'In the beginning, I was very diligent, more than other believers from Muslim backgrounds': Grégory's conversion to Islam
subhead: 'Changing Faith' (3/11). Why do people choose a particular religion? Attracted from a young age to Islam, Grégory Gonty, a 35-year-old Belgian social worker, became Muslim at the age of 21. The fervent believer has since become a knowledgeable and inquisitive practitioner.
